article_title: ADA Obligations Of Health Providers Are Magnified By ACA
article_text:
ADA Obligations Of Health Providers Are Magnified By ACA

Law360, New York (February 27, 2014, 6:03 PM ET) -- America's heated health care policy debates have taken place against the backdrop of significant enforcement and regulatory activity under the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 and other disability statutes. Much of this recent activity has been targeted at health care providers, which fall within the definition of “public accommodations” under Titles II and III of the ADA, affecting public and private entities respectively. article_metadata.description: Given the stated importance of health care providers complying with the Americans with Disabilities Act at all stages of the U.S. Department of Justice's "Barrier-Free Health Care" initiative — which enforces provisions of the Affordable Care Act — an attempt could be made to exclude non-ADA-compliant facilities from the network of providers permitted to serve dual-eligible patients, say Frank Morris and Andrea Calem of Epstein Becker & Green PC.
